entire functions

A function f ⁣:C→C\func{f}{\C}{\C}f:C→C is entire and has the property that ∣f(z)∣=1\abs{f\p{z}} = 1∣f(z)∣=1 when ∣z∣=1\abs{z} = 1∣z∣=1. Prove that f(z)=aznf\p{z} = az^nf(z)=azn for some integer n≥0n \geq 0n≥0 and some a∈Ca \in \Ca∈C with ∣a∣=1\abs{a} = 1∣a∣=1.
Solution.

Since fff is not identically zero, its zeroes cannot accumulate, so in particular, fff can only have finitely many zeroes a1,…,an∈D‾a_1, \ldots, a_n \in \cl{\D}a1​,…,an​∈D counting multiplicity. Since fff does not vanish on the boundary, we see that each ak∈Da_k \in \Dak​∈D. Thus, the Blaschke product

B(z)=∏k=1nz−ak1−ak‾zB\p{z} = \prod_{k=1}^n \frac{z - a_k}{1 - \conj{a_k}z}B(z)=k=1∏n​1−ak​​zz−ak​​

is a holomorphic function such that ∣B(z)∣=1\abs{B\p{z}} = 1∣B(z)∣=1 on ∂D\partial\D∂D with exactly the same zeroes as fff counting multiplicity. Thus, if g=fBg = \frac{f}{B}g=Bf​, then ggg is holomorphic and non-zero on D\DD, so 1g\frac{1}{g}g1​ is also holomorphic on D\DD. Observe that on ∂D\partial\D∂D,

∣g(z)∣=1∣g(z)∣=1,\abs{g\p{z}} = \frac{1}{\abs{g\p{z}}} = 1,∣g(z)∣=∣g(z)∣1​=1,

so by the maximum principle applied to both ggg and 1g\frac{1}{g}g1​, we get ∣g(z)∣=1\abs{g\p{z}} = 1∣g(z)∣=1 on all of D\DD. Thus, ggg is constant on D\DD, i.e., for any z∈Dz \in \Dz∈D,

g(z)=a  ⟹  f(z)=a∏k=1nz−ak1−ak‾zg\p{z} = a \implies f\p{z} = a\prod_{k=1}^n \frac{z - a_k}{1 - \conj{a_k}z}g(z)=a⟹f(z)=ak=1∏n​1−ak​​zz−ak​​

for some a∈Ca \in \Ca∈C with ∣a∣=1\abs{a} = 1∣a∣=1. Thus, by uniqueness and connectedness, we have f=Bf = Bf=B on their common domain of holomorphicity. If any ak≠0a_k \neq 0ak​=0, then fff would have a pole at 1/ak‾1/\conj{a_k}1/ak​​, which is impossible since fff is entire. Thus, fff can only have zeroes at the origin, so f(z)=aznf\p{z} = az^nf(z)=azn.
